title: How do blankets keep you warm? - Quora

response.answer_text: The warmth is generated by the person, the blanket simply slows the rate of heat loss. The less heat lost, the warmer it feels. The key to this is air trapped in the blanket itself. Air is not a good heat conductor, so the more air trapped, the greater the insulating value and the warmer it feels. In general the thicker the blanket, the more air it traps and the warmer you feel. This is why down comforters feel so warm. The down in them traps a great deal of air because they are very thick, so they feel very warm. Multiple blankets (layers) also tend to feel warm because of the air trapped between the layers in addition to the blankets themselves. Also, for a given thickness, lighter blankets will be feel warmer because they will have less conductive heat loss. Reflective “space blankets” are a quite different. They are usually impervious so they trap air (and moisture) under them and they are also shiny which reduces radiant heat loss. They are not ideal for daily use because of their moisture entrapment.

You are actually keeping yourself warm with the heat your body produces. The blanket helps insulate you from the temperature of the room, which is less than 98.6F. Without the blanket, you lose body heat. But the blanket serves as a barrier, keeping the warmth you create trapped beneath where you can enjoy it.

The air trapped between the skin and the blanket provides insulation to keep in your body heat. Same idea as with clothing. The blanket and clothing material have some insulation effect as well, but air has much more insulating affect because the thermal conductivity of air is so low. That’s why multiple layers of thin material are better at keeping you warm than one layer of thicker material because more air is trapped. That’s why covering yourself with a newspaper keeps you so warm - multiple layers.

Human body (any object whose temperature is higher than absolute zero) is continuously radiating infrared light, which is the source of heat to some extent. The blanket serves as a infrared light reflection layer to reflect the lost heat back to human body to keep it warm.You can imagine that the clothes you wear sever in the same way.

The blanket acts as an insulator and the body heat (yes, we do give off heat when we are alive) will heat the air between your body and the blanket. The net result is that you feel warm or hot depending on the ambient temperature….if the room is chilly, there would be some loss of heat through the blanket and you may feel snug and warm…if the room itself is warm or hot, you would not need a blanket but if you cover yourself for some reason, you may feel very hot under that sheet…

Cold air tries to carry your body heat away. Blankets form a barrier between your body and that cold air. Since heat doesn't transfer through the blankets very well, they keep the heat from getting out. The colder the surroundings are, the more insulation you need to keep your body heat from escaping too fast.

Wear extra layers of loose-fitting clothing as needed. Use extra blankets or asleeping bag to keep yourself warm. Make sure your home is heated appropriately. Apply a warm compress (heating pad or hot water bottle wrapped in a towel) to body areas for added heat.
